Author: Morris, J. M., & Wigan, M. R.
Title: A family expenditure perspective on transport planning: Australian evidence in context
Brief summary of what the study is about: Taking household expenditure data collected in Australia, they summarized and observed patterns in the data. The looked at things like the percentage of transportation expenses compared to total expenses, the transportation expenses with respect to car ownership, transportation and communication expenses. They also looked at other expense data sources to get a view of other contries. They concluded that expenditure data can reveal patterns that will help transportation planners.
Main Findings: transport takes about o17 percent of expenditures, at least part of the consumption expenditure by low income families is financed from savings, loans or other sources besides "income".

Author: Skinner
Title: Variable Lifespan and the Intertemporal Elasticity of Consumption
Brief summary of what the study is about: Used CES to estimate the interest sensitivity of consumpiton. The results suggest that elasticity is higher than previously thought
Main Findings: Changes in inflation will prompt changes in consumer expenditures

Author: Nayga
Title: A sample selection model for prepared food expenditures
Brief summary of what the study is about: Examined expenditures on prepared food products.
Main Findings: Most of the variables analysed significantly affect prepared food expenditures. For example, results suggest that frozen meals expenditures are higher for households without children, for smaller households, and for households headed by a non-white individual
Main Outcome Variables: Frozen meals, other prepared food, prepared salads, desserts
Independent Variables: Presence of children, number or earners, region, household size, seasonality, age, race, education, and income

Author: Blumenberg, E.
Title: Transportation Costs and Economic Opportunity Among the Poor
Main Findings: Cost comparisons fall short of finding if transportation costs are a barrier for economic opportunity among the poor

Author: Thakuriah, P. (Vonu), & Liao, Y.
Title: Analysis of Variations in Vehicle Ownership Expenditures
Main Findings: For vehicle-owning households, of every additional dollar that households spend, 18 cents is spent on vehicles after controlling for socioeconomic, demographic, life cycle, and other factors relating to households.
Independent Variables: total expenditure, age of reference, number of children, homeowner, education, workers, etc.

Author: Hong, G.-S., Fan, J. X., Palmer, L., & Bhargava, V.
Title: Leisure Travel Expenditure Patterns by Family Life Cycle Stages
Main Findings: Marrieds without children are more likely to spend on leisure travel than singles, whereas single parents and solitary survivors are less likely to spend on leisure travel than singles.
Main Outcome Variables: Regression for categories: Transportation, Lodging, Food, and Entertainment
Independent Variables: Married without children, full nest, empty nest, single parents, income, home ownership

Author: Thakuriah (Vonu), P., & Liao, Y.
Title: Transportation Expenditures and Ability to Pay: Evidence from Consumer Expenditure Survey
Main Findings: Transportation expenditures made by households are better explained by permanent income levels of households than by annual incomes.
Independent Variables: HH Demographics, spatial factors, economic factors, family conditioning factors

Author: Fontes and Fan
Title: The Effects of Ethnic Identity on Household Budget Allocation to Status Conveying Goods
Brief summary of what the study is about: They wanted to see if a household's ethnic identity affects its budget allocation to status conveying goods. The four ethnicities they looked at were European American, Asian American, Hispanic, African American. Findings suggest that Asian Americans allocate more of their budget to housing, African Americans allocate more of their budget to apparel, and Hispanics allocate more of their budget to both housing and apparel, but to a lesser extent than Asian Americans with respect to housing and African Americans with respect to apparel.
Main Findings: Asian Americans allocate more of their budget to housing, African Americans allocate more of their budget to apparel, and Hispanics allocate more of their budget to both housing and apparel, but to a lesser extent than Asian Americans with respect to housing and African Americans with respect to apparel.
Independent Variables: Age, occupation, family composition, family type, housing tenure, region, etc

Author: Choo, S., Lee, T., & Mokhtarian, P. L.
Title: Do Transportation and Communications Tend to be Substitutes, Complements, or Neither?: U.S. Consumer Expenditures Perspective, 1984–2002
Main Findings: New tech doesn't substitue Personal Vehicle travel probably

Author: Copperman, R. B., & Bhat, C. R.
Title: An analysis of the determinants of children’s weekend physical activity participation
Dataset Location: San Francisco Bay Area Travel Survey
Main Findings: The “number of children” variable suggests an overall  higher likelihood of participation in utilitarian active travel among households with many children  relative to households with few children
Main Outcome Variables: Passive Travel, Utilitarian Active Travel, Active Recreation
Independent Variables: Age, Household structure and other demographics, Land-use variables

Author: Sener, I. N., & Bhat, C. R.
Title: An analysis of the social context of children’s weekend discretionary activity participation
Main Findings: male children more likely to participate with their fathers than female children, African-American children less likely to  participate in health-enhancing active recreation pursuits
Main Outcome Variables: Child's age, male, race, physically challenged
Independent Variables: Activity purpose, company type, purpose and company interactions

Author: Copperman, R. B., & Bhat, C. R.
Title: An Exploratory Analysis of Children’s Daily Time-Use and Activity Patterns Using the Child Development Supplement (CDS) to the US Panel Study of Income Dynamics (PSID)
Main Findings: The age of childrend has an effect on the types of activities they pursue

Author: Haas, P. M., Makarewicz, C., Benedict, A., & Bernstein, S.
Title: Estimating Transportation Costs by Characteristics of Neighborhood and Household
Main Findings: Their model can help in travel demand modeling
Main Outcome Variables: cars owned, miles driven, trips taken

Author: Sener, I. N., Copperman, R. B., Pendyala, R. M., & Bhat, C. R.
Title: An analysis of children’s leisure activity engagement: Examining the day of week, location, physical activity level, and fixity dimensions
Main Findings: Children in households with  parents who are employed, higher income, or higher education were found to participate in  structured outdoor activities at higher rates.
Main Outcome Variables: child age, male, child race, physically challenged
Independent Variables: activity info, interactions of activity info

Author: Ferdous, N., Pinjari, A. R., Bhat, C. R., & Pendyala, R. M.
Title: A comprehensive analysis of household transportation expenditures relative to other goods and services: An application to United States consumer expenditure data
Main Findings: Adjustments are made with increased fuel prices

Author: Souche, Stephanie
Title: Measuring the Structureal Determinants of Urban Travel Demand
Main Findings: urban density and cost of transport mode were statisticalliy significan in their model
Main Outcome Variables: Daily car trips and daily transit trips
Independent Variables: cost of car, availability of car, income, urban structure

Author: Paleti, R., Copperman, R. B., & Bhat, C. R.
Title: An empirical analysis of children’s after school out-of-home activity-location engagement patterns and time allocation
Main Findings: The results show that a wide variety of demographic, attitudinal,  environmental, and others’ activity-travel pattern characteristics impact children’s after school  activity engagement patterns.

Author: Sabelhaus, J., Johnson, D., Ash, S., Swanson, D., Garner, T., Greenlees, J., & Henderson, S.
Title: Is the Consumer Expenditure Survey Representative by Income?
Main Findings: the highest income thresholds are underrepresented in the survey

Author: Deka, D.
Title: Relationship between Households’ Housing and Transportation Expenditures: Examination from Lifestyle Perspective
Main Findings: More housing costs = more transportation costs, people the take transit spend less on transportation

Author: Bernardo, C., Paleti, R., Hoklas, M., & Bhat, C.
Title: An empirical investigation into the time-use and activity patterns of dual-earner couples with and without young children
Main Findings: the presence  of a child in dual-earner households not only leads to a reduction in in-home non-work activity  participation (excluding child care activities) but also a substantially larger decrease in out-of-home non-work activity participation (excluding child care and shopping activities),

Author: Lino, M., Kuczynski, K., Rodriguez, N., & Schap, T.
Title: Expenditures on Children by Families, 2015
Main Findings: Many observations on the expenditures of children

Author: McCarthy, L., Delbosc, A., Currie, G., & Molloy, A.
Title: Factors influencing travel mode choice among families with young children (aged 0–4): A review of the literature
Main Findings: many factores influence decisions about mode choice when traveling with young children.

Author: Mattson, J., & Peterson, D.
Title: Relationships between Land Use, Transportation, Household Expenditures, and Municipal Spending in Small Urban Areas
Main Findings: denser areas are more likely to use transit to commute. People in single-family homes tend to spend more money on transportation
Main Outcome Variables: Likelyhood of any Tranist Commuter in Census Block Group

Author: Leung, K. Y. K., Astroza, S., Loo, B. P. Y., & Bhat, C. R.
Title: An environment-people interactions framework for analysing children’s extra-curricular activities and active transport
Main Findings: childrens activities can differ a lot based on neighborhood enfironment and family sociodemographic background.

Author: Mattson, J.
Title: Relationships between density, transit, and household expenditures in small urban areas
Main Findings: single family homes spend more on transportation, higher income is correlated with higher tranportation costs.

Author: Osborne, C., Wu, E., & Benson, K.
Title: An Updated Estimation Model of the Cost of Raising Children in Texas
Main Findings: Regardless of the method of calculation, we find that it is nearly impossible for two minimum wage earners to meet the basic costs of raising children in Texas, especially when child care is included

Author: Hastings, O. P.
Title: Parental Investments of Money for White, Black, and Hispanic Children in the United States
Main Findings: . Both sociodemographic and economic factors play a substantial role in these differences, and the racial and ethnic gaps in parental investments of money are nearly eliminated when both are accounted for

Author: Lu, Y., Prato, C. G., Sipe, N., Kimpton, A., & Corcoran, J.
Title: The role of household modality style in first and last mile travel mode choice
Main Findings: joint travel contributes least to modal shift from car to active transport when there is improved infrastructure of trains and things
Main Outcome Variables: utilities of walking and taking a car to transit travel

Author: Amirnazmiafshar, E., & Diana, M.
Title: A review of the socio-demographic characteristics affecting the demand for different car-sharing operational schemes
Main Findings: There are lots of factors that might affect people's willingness to use car sharing

Author: Duncan, K. A., Frank, K., & Guèvremont, A.
Title: Estimating Expenditures on Children by Families in Canada, 2014 to 2017
Main Findings: The more income, the more spending on kids.
Independent Variables: income group, number of children in household, age of youngest child.

Author: Molloy, Q., Garrick, N., & Atkinson-Palombo, C.
Title: A New Approach to Understanding the Impact of Automobile Ownership on Transportation Equity
Main Findings: "Captive Riders" have less spending allocated to transportation than captive drivers.

Author: Bureau of Transportation Statistics.
Title: Transportation Statistics Annual Report 2024
Main Findings: Lots of summaries

Author: Hargunani, C., Vernekar, S., & Vernekar, S.
Title: A STUDY OF SPENDING, SAVING AND INVESTMENT PATTERNS OF MARRIED COUPLES WITH CHILDREN(NON-DINK) IN MUMBAI
Main Findings: The data analysis reveals distinct spending, saving, and investment patterns among married couples, with a clear prioritization towards ensuring the well-being and future security of their families.”

Author: Klein, N. J.
Title: Subsidizing Car Ownership for Low-Income Individuals and Households
Dataset Location: Personal Survey Created by Dr. Klein
Main Findings: Having a car gave people more opportunities than before, and they usually had more time to spend with the family. At the beginning and end of the day.

Author: Bilgin, P., Mattioli, G., Morgan, M., & Wadud, Z.
Title: Investigating the effects of ridesourcing on the dynamics of household car ownership
Main Findings: Suggests that households are less likely to qcquire a car in the presence of ridesourcing, but car disposal is mainly driven by household compositions and residential relocation factors.
